summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas today entered a final judgment against a former employee of the Public Works Department of El Paso, Texas, who has agreed to settle a civil injunctive action brought by the District Attorney's Office against her.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in El Paso on April 13, 2015, alleges that, beginning in 2000 or 2001, Monique Monique Aguilar complained to her supervisors and human resources personnel that she was being harassed by Manny Lucero, a former supervisor of the department's public works department. According to the complaint, Aguilar raised the matter with her supervisor, Norma Palacios, who was her supervisor at the time, and told her that Lucero was "in over his head" and "in lieu of a woman." The complaint further alleges that Aguilar replied that she had "forget the past, made amends with [Lucero] in lieu of [her] being [treated] with [sic] that she could not do the job of." Aguilar resigned her position on April 16, 2015. The complaint charges Aguilar with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty. Aguilar has also agreed to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins her from future violations of the federal securities laws. The settlement is subject to court approval.  In a parallel action, the Texas Attorney General's Office today announced criminal charges against Aguilar. The SEC also announced that it has obtained an emergency court order freezing Aguilar's assets and ordering her to return to her duties as a public works employee. The court's order freezes the assets of Aguilar and her employer, and orders Aguilar to pay a civil monetary penalty of $100,000. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay, Chief of the Department of Public Works. The litigation will be led by John Rymas and supervised by Amy Gwiazda of the SEC's Fort Worth Regional Office.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Texas Office of Inspector General, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Texas Department of Health and Human Services in this matter.
